Aiming at the valorization of furfural-derived compounds, the potential of (La-)NiCu catalysts for the hydrodeoxygenation of 4-(2-furanyl)-3-buten-2-one has been assessed. The impact of support acidity and the effects of modifying the support with La have been explored. While catalysts with non-acidic supports solely lead to hydrogenation, the acid sites enable furanic ring opening. Additionally, changing the support alters the metal-support interaction strength, with stronger interactions reducing the NiCu alloy particle size and increasing activity. Furthermore, according to Density of States calculations, La further enhances the hydrodeoxygenation activity by increasing the adsorption strength. Also, for the acidic supports, it increases the relative abundance of NiCu alloy on the support surface, further increasing the specific activity. The La-NiCu-Al catalyst demonstrated was the best performing catalyst at 200 °C and 40 bar H2, achieving a high conversion rate of 77 mol kgcat −1 h−1 with a combined selectivity of 29 % towards octane and BTHF at 99 % conversion, and stability over 5 hours Time-On-Stream. Additionally, isopropyl alcohol proved to be an excellent hydrogen donor, as the external H2 pressure does not substantially impact the catalyst activity and selectivity, but H2 itself proved to be important for the catalyst stability. Graphical Abstract Keywords 4-(2-furanyl)-3-buten-2-one Acidity Furfural Hydrodeoxygenation Furfural−acetone adduct In-situ supported catalysts NiCu Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction There is an urgent global imperative to shift away from non-renewable (fossil) feedstocks and reduce greenhouse gas emissions [1,2]. Within this context, biomass resources are emerging as a promising and environmentally friendly alternative for the production of fuels and value-added chemicals. In particular, lignocellulosic biomass holds great interest due to its abundant availability and its non-competitive nature with food production [3,4]. Biorefineries are the key to achieving this transition as they enable the conversion of biomass resources into high-value products while simultaneously minimizing waste and mitigating environmental impact [5]. From the legislative side, the drive to advance in this respect is evidenced by initiatives such as the European Green Deal and the U.S. Inflation Reduction Act [6,7]. Among various objectives, there is a push to augment the proportion of sustainable aviation fuels to reduce greenhouse gas emissions within this sector [8,9]. Furfural is a platform molecule obtained via the conversion of lignocellulosic biomass' constituent sugars via a series of steps, including hydrolysis and dehydration. It plays a vital role in biorefineries, as it serves as a building block for a wide range of chemicals and materials [2,5,10,11]. However, for direct use as an aviation fuel, the carbon number of furfural is too low, as kerosene type molecules typically contain between 8 and 16 carbon atoms [12]. To overcome this issue, furfural can be subjected to aldol condensation with acetone, which converts it into products in the range of C8-C13, including 4-(2-furyl)-3-buten-2-one (FAc) [2,11,13]. Note that the second reactant, i.e., acetone, can also be produced in a renewable way through the conversion of renewable acetic acid or the fermentation of sugars [14–16]. Despite the potential of these furfural-derived compounds, their oxygen groups and double bonds make them less stable and less energy-dense than conventional fuels [2,17]. Consequently, stabilizing these components, e.g., by hydrodeoxygenation (HDO), is necessary to improve their fuel properties. HDO is a reaction in which H2 is used to reduce the oxygen content of hydrocarbons, which has been recommended by Bond et al. through their techno-economical evaluation of a process similar to the one described above [11]. Moreover, in their work, the use of Pt-based catalysts in the HDO step, prompted the suggestion to explore more cost-effective metals as HDO catalysts to curtail capital expenditure. However, despite the indicated cost, Pt-based catalysts remained being investigated, particularly to elucidate what makes these catalysts perform well for HDO of FAc. To understand the effect of support used in Pt-based catalysts, Ramos et al. varied the support over SiO2, Al2O3, TiO2, hydrotalcite, Beta zeolite, Al-SBA-15 and WO3-ZrO2 at 200 °C and 50 bar H2 [18]. It was found that the Pt particle size, which is contingent upon the strength of metal-support interactions and, hence, the support employed, affects the hydrogenation of furanic and ketonic groups. Furthermore, support acidity was found to promote ring opening, dehydration and aldol condensation steps [18]. Similar conclusions were corroborated by Faba et al. for analogous Pt-based catalysts, underlining the importance of metal dispersion and support acidity [19]. Moreover, these authors identified coke formation to be the main deactivation mechanism, related to the inherent acidity of the Al2O3 support. In a follow-up study, Ramos et al. delved into solvent effects of both protic and aprotic solvents in the hydrodeoxygenation of furfural-acetone aldol condensation products over Pt-TiO2 catalysts, revealing a positive, linear correlation between the initial rate of hydrogenation and the dielectric constant of protic solvents [20]. Among the solvents tested, isopropyl alcohol, the solvent with the highest dielectric constant, was found to be the most effective. In contrast, the hydrogenation activity in the presence of aprotic solvents was negatively correlated to solvent-catalyst interactions, such as the solvent desorption enthalpy. Additionally, it was mentioned that the solubility of FAc in some aprotic solvents is low, rendering them less useful for industrial processes. Later research explored the use of novel catalysts to reduce the cost associated with the HDO catalyst, such as the use of heteropolyacids, bifunctional noble metal-loaded polymer-silica composite catalysts and NiCu-Al-SBA-15 catalysts [21–23]. However, non-noble metal based supported catalysts have been scarcely studied for FAc HDO, making the latter research about NiCu-Al-SBA-15 catalysts especially interesting. The work demonstrated that the NiCu-based catalysts outperform the reference noble metal-based catalysts at the operating conditions employed and indicated that the acid sites of Al-SBA-15 were crucial to initiate ring opening, comparable to the Pt-based catalysts described above [23]. Furthermore, while NiCu-Nb2O5 has exhibited promising performance in FAc HDO, the costliness of its support undermines its economic viability [24]. Further investigation into the catalytic chemistry and stability remains imperative to unlock the full potential of these materials. NiCu-based catalysts have also been used in a related catalytic HDO reaction with anisole as a model compound for pyrolysis oil [25]. For anisole HDO, the importance of acid sites was observed as well, where γ-Al2O3-based catalysts are able to demethoxylate methoxycyclohexane, whilst SiO2-based catalysts cannot [26]. In a follow-up work, La was added sequentially to the γ-Al2O3-supported catalysts, which effectively limited the formation of the inactive monometallic Cu0 phase that is unfortunately present in the unpromoted catalysts [26]. This was related to an intimate contact between La and the NiCu phase, yielding more stable alloys, which interestingly resulted in a higher HDO selectivity. Additionally, modification of the γ-Al2O3 surface by La2O3 deposition led to an increased stability as well. The present work investigates these promising NiCu-based catalysts for FAc HDO, assessing the impact of support acidity and the effects of modifying the support with La. Additionally, the total pressure and reaction temperature were varied to probe their impact on the reaction chemistry. Lastly, the catalysts were tested into a continuous set-up to evaluate their stability. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation A series of non-promoted and La promoted supported NiCu catalysts were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation. SiO2 (CARiACT Q-10, Fuji Silycia Chemical Ltd.), γ-Al2O3 (PURALOX SCCa150/200, Sasol) and Siral1 (γ-Al2O3 doped with 1 wt% SiO2, Siral 1, Sasol) were used as support. In each catalyst, the total loading of Ni and Cu amounted to 20 wt% with a Ni/Cu (mol/mol) ratio of 1/1. The La promotor loading amounted to 0.5 wt%, to have a total metal loading of 20.5 wt% for each La promoted catalyst. The required amounts of both metal salt precursors, i.e. Cu(NO3)2·3 H2O (99,5%, VWR) and Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O (99,999%, Sigma Aldrich), were simultaneously dissolved in a volume of water equal to that of the pore volume of the support. The solution was added dropwise to the support under constant stirring. Afterwards, the catalysts were dried at 120 °C for 12 h and then calcined at 450 °C for 4 h in air. For the La promoted catalysts, La(NO3)3·6 H2O (99,999%, Sigma Aldrich) was added sequentially before impregnation with Ni and Cu, with an intermittent calcination at the aforementioned conditions. The following convention was used for labeling the various catalysts: Promotor - NiCu – support, e.g. La-NiCu-Al is a La promoted catalyst on the γ-Al2O3 support, while NiCu-Siral is a non-promoted catalyst with Siral1 as support. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The specific surface area and pore volume of each catalyst were determined using a Micromeritics TriStar II 3020 instrument. To obtain the N2 adsorption-desorption curve, a sample of approximately 50 mg was degassed at 300°C for 3 hours to remove any volatile adsorbates from the surface and subsequently subject to the measurement at −196 °C. The specific surface area was determined using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method and the average pore volume was calculated using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. The measurements were performed three times using a different batch of the same catalyst to obtain mean values and corresponding 95% confidence intervals. To determine the concentration of acid sites, ammonia (NH3) Temperature Programmed Desorption (TPD) was performed using an Autochem 2920 instrument coupled with a Thermal Conductivity Detector (TCD) and a Mass Spectrometer (MS) to validate the measured TCD signal. Prior to analysis, the materials were subjected to purging with high purity helium (50 cm³ min−1) at 120 °C for 1 hour to eliminate water, followed by further purging at 200 °C for 5 minutes to remove any other potentially adsorbed products. The catalysts were then reduced in-situ under 5% H2/Ar (60 cm³ min−1) at 450 °C for 30 minutes. Subsequently, a 4% NH3/He flow (75 cm³ min−1) was used for 1 hour at 150 °C to saturate the catalysts, and then the materials were purged with helium (60 cm³ min−1) for 1 hour to remove physisorbed NH3. The temperature was subsequently gradually increased to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1, while continuously monitoring the release of NH3. Using the same Autochem 2920 instrument, also a Temperature Programmed Reduction (TPR) was carried out to gain insights into the reduction properties of the phases present on the catalysts. To conduct the TPR, a U-shaped tubular quartz reactor containing approximately 100 mg of a calcined catalyst was used, with a thermocouple carefully placed within the catalyst bed. Prior to the measurement, the sample was purged with argon (50 cm³ min−1) at 120 °C for 1 hour and then at 200 °C for 5 minutes. The reduction was then conducted using 5% H2/Ar (60 cm³ min−1) from 50 °C to 800 °C and a dwell time of 30 minutes with a temperature ramp of 10 °C min−1. The crystal structures were determined by performing powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements using a Siemens Diffractometer Kristalloflex D5000 with Cu Kα radiation. Prior to the XRD analysis, the catalysts were crushed into a fine powder and reduced in an Autochem 2920 instrument at 450 °C for 30 minutes. To minimize exposure to air, the samples were stored and transferred in high purity argon. The diffractograms were obtained in the 2θ range from 10° to 110° with a step size of 0.02 s−1 and 10 s collection time. Peak identification was performed using Crystallographic Information Files available in the Crystallography Open Database i.e. Cu [27], NiCu [28], NiO [29] and γ-Al2O3 [30]. To obtain information about the metal particle size, the catalyst structure, and elemental maps at a local level, scanning transmission electron microscopy combined with energy dispersive X-ray (STEM-EDX) was conducted using a JEOL JEM-2200FS Cs-corrected microscope, equipped with a Schottky-type Field-Emission Gun (FEG) operated at 200 kV and EDX JEOL JED-2300D. Prior to the analysis, the catalysts were reduced at 450 °C for 30 minutes in an Autochem 2920 instrument, and precautions were taken to minimize exposure to air by storing and transferring them in an Ar environment. The samples were placed on a gold grid support with a lacey carbon film before analysis. The particle size distribution was determined by counting 200 particles. To verify the dispersion of the NiCu catalysts, CO and H2 chemisorption was at-tempted but neither of them gave accurate results compared to the mean particle size obtained via TEM, as has been seen before in literature [31,32]. A N2O-based procedure for Cu catalysts described by Gervasini et al. was also attempted, but also did not lead to accurate data, most likely due to the presence of other metal and oxide phases on the catalyst, such as Cu and NiO [25,26,33]. Mass loss upon heating was assessed via TGA using a Setaram SETSYS Evolution TGA-DTA Thermal Analyzer equipped with a Pfeiffer Omnistar GSD 320 MS. About 25 mg of catalyst was heated from room temperature to 700 °C. 20 mL min−1 of synthetic air was used with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. Before the start of the temperature ramp, the sample was stabilized at 30 °C under the air flow for 20 minutes. All Density of States calculations in this work were performed using a plane-wave density functional theory (DFT) approach with the projector-augmented wave (PAW) method [34,35] in conjunction with a Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) exchange-correlation functional as implemented in Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) [36,37]. The kinetic energy cutoff for the plane-wave basis was set to 500 eV. A Monkhorst-pack 5×5x5 mesh of k-points was used. Electronic convergence was set to 10−5 eV. Partial electron occupancies close to the Fermi level were considered using a second-order Methfessel-Paxton scheme with a smearing width of 0.2 eV. Since Ni has an uneven pair of electrons, spin polarization was taken into account. Filled d-band centres were calculated using the formula (1) ε d = ∫ − ∞ 0 n d ( ε ) ε d ε ∫ − ∞ 0 n d ( ε ) d ε with nd the d-band density. The reference NiCu alloy is modelled using an FCC unit cell consisting of 5 Ni atoms and 3 Cu atoms. Once La is added, a unit cell of 32 atoms is considered to realistically model the amount of La present if one of the atoms is replaced by La. All structures were relaxed until the maximal force on any atom was less than 20 meV/Å before doing DOS calculations. 2.3 Catalyst performance testing 2.3.1 Experimental assessment of catalyst performance The catalyst performance was assessed using a 300 mL high-pressure batch reactor (Parr Instruments Co.). Approximately 0.2 g of the catalyst was added to the reactor vessel and then reduced in a continuous H2 (≥ 99,99%, Air Liquide) flow at 450 °C with a stirring speed of 300 rpm for 30 min. After cooling down to room temperature, 1 g of 4-(2-furyl)-3-buten-2-one (FAc, cis + trans, 98%, Merck), 1 g of decane (>= 95%, Sigma Aldrich) as internal standard and 150 mL of isopropyl alcohol (100%, Lachner) were loaded into the reactor. Blank experiments validated that the internal standard remained inert throughout the reactions. Beforehand, the catalyst was crushed, sieved and pelletized until a particle size of 75 – 100 µm was achieved. The system was thoroughly purged for 15 min, with H2 or N2 (≥ 99,999%, Air Liquide), depending on the experiment to be performed. Subsequently, the reactor was pressurized (10 bar) to avoid boiling, with either N2 or H2, under slow stirring (300 rpm) and then heated up to the desired reaction temperature. Once the temperature was reached, the stirring speed was set to 1000 rpm and the system pressurized to the desired reaction pressure, and the start time was noted. Samples were taken at regular time intervals during the course of the reaction, i.e. at the start and after 5, 10, 20, 40, 60, 90, 120, 180 and 240 min. The materials’ stability was assessed by performing continuous flow experimentation using a high-pressure tubular reactor, which consisted of a 50 cm long stainless-steel tube with an internal diameter of 1.146 cm. Before loading, the catalysts were crushed, sieved and pelletized until a particle size in the range of 75 – 100 µm was obtained. The catalyst bed was packed in the middle of the reactor between two layers consisting of SiC (POLPUR, spol.) particles. The catalyst bed itself was diluted to 10 wt% of catalyst with inert α-alumina (> 99.75%, Final). Prior to reaction, the catalyst was reduced by heating to 450 °C with a ramp rate of 5 °C/min in a 100 mL/min N2 flow. After reaching the desired reduction temperature, the gas was switched to H2 at a flow rate of 100 mL/min for 1 h at atmospheric pressure. Both N2 and H2, depending on the experiment, were used as a gas feed, while an identical mixture as used in the batch experiments served as the liquid feed. The acquisition of catalyst performance data was carried out under the following reaction conditions: a temperature of 200 °C, a pressure of 4.0 MPa and a N2 or H2 to FAc ratio ( mol N 2 or H 2 mol FAc − 1 ) of 150. The process parameters were controlled by making use of, respectively, a thermocouple inside the catalyst bed, a back-pressure regulator (Equilibar, USA), a HPLC pump (P102 Pump, Watrex Praha) and a gas flow controller (Bronkhorst, The Netherlands). A space time of either 80 or 160 kg s mol−1 was used depending on the activity of the material to achieve starting conversions below 100%. 2.3.2 Sample analysis and data treatment The batch and continuous flow samples were analyzed off-line by using an Agilent 7820 gas chromatography unit equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and an HP-5 capillary column (30 m/0.32 mm ID/0.25 µm) for quantification. A GC-MS (Agilent 7820, HP-5 capillary column (30 m/0.32 mm ID/0.25 µm)) was used for identification purposes. The conversion of FAc ( X FAc ) was defined on molar basis and is calculated according to Eq. (2): (2) X FAc = Q FAc 0 − Q FAc Q FAc 0 where Q FAc 0 and Q FAc are respectively the initial moles (or molar flow in mol/s in continuous flow) of FAc at the start of the experiment and at a certain time in batch reaction or at the end of the reactor in continuous flow. Because of the high hydrogenation activity of each catalyst, X FAc quickly rises to close to 100%. Therefore, also a modified conversion was defined in Eq. (2), which accounts for the conversion of 4-(2-furyl)-butan-2-one (HFAc) towards secondary products: (3) X FAc − HFAc = Q FAc 0 − Q FAc − Q HFAc Q FAc 0 The carbon selectivity towards a non-primary product k ( S k ) was calculated by Eq. (4): (4) S k = n k Q k 8 ( Q FAc 0 − Q FAc − Q HFAc ) where n k the number of carbon atoms present in a molecule of product k. The yield towards a product k (Yk) at a certain conversion XFAc-HFAc was calculated by making use of the selectivities (Sk) at that conversion via Eq. (4): (5) Y k = X FAc − HFAc S k Finally, the specific reaction rate (mol kgcat −1 h−1) towards non-primary products after 5 min in the batch reactor (R5 min) was calculated via Eq. (5): (6) R 5 min = Q FAc 0 − Q FAc − Q H − FAc 5 min 60 min h . w cat where wcat is the catalyst mass used in the experiment. 3 Results and discussion The catalyst characterization results are reported first, followed by the catalyst screening where the impact of the support acidity and La addition is assessed. As part of the interpretation of the screening data, the characterization results are linked with the catalyst performance, i.e. activity, selectivity and stability. Finally, the impact of reaction pressure and temperature on the catalyst performance has been probed, including the use of a H2-free atmosphere. 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 Textural, acidic and reduction properties N2-sorption measurements were used to determine the BET surface area and pore volume, which are provided in Table 1 (see ESI Fig. S3 for the isotherms). All the calcined supports and catalysts exhibit a type IV isotherm with H2-type hysteresis, indicating the presence of mesoporosity in the materials with an undefined distribution of pore sizes, pore shapes and pore necks [38,39]. Comparing the BET surface area and pore volume of the corresponding supports and synthesized catalysts, a decrease upon metal deposition is generally observed. These changes are attributed to variations in density after impregnation and calcination to metal oxides, which is significant given the 20 wt% loading, as well as the blockage of pores due to the formation of nanoparticles on the support surface. Additionally, no significant difference is observed in BET surface area and pore volume between the promoted and the unpromoted catalysts. The quantification of acid sites was performed using NH3-TPD. The corresponding results can be found in Table 1 (see ESI Fig. S4 for the desorption profiles). No significant formation of N2 or H2 was observed during the experiment, indicating that possible NH3 decomposition on the metal sites can be disregarded. As expected, the pristine silica support exhibits a negligible acidity (only 1 μmol g−1), while the γ-Al2O3 and Siral support have significantly higher acid site concentrations, i.e., 340 μmol g−1 and 254 μmol g−1, respectively. Prior literature has reported as well that Siral has, compared to γ-Al2O3, less or similar Lewis acidity in both strength and amount [40–42]. After impregnation, both the non-promoted and promoted SiO2 catalysts do not exhibit any acidity, similar to the pristine support. For the γ-Al2O3 and Siral support, a decrease in acidity is observed after impregnation and reduction, which can be attributed to the coverage of Lewis acid sites by the metal nanoparticles and changes in material density due to the impregnation and calcination of the metals. Additionally, pore blockage may contribute to a further decrease in the concentration of acid sites for both the non-promoted and the promoted catalysts. The maximum of the desorption peak, related to the strength of the acid sites, was similar for all materials and was thus not further investigated [43,44]. The reducibility of the calcined catalysts was evaluated using H2-TPR, as shown in Fig. 1. Each sample exhibits up to four peaks, indicating hydrogen consumption. The first peak, observed at low temperatures (150–220 °C), corresponds to the reduction of Cu2+ to Cu0 [45,46]. The second and third peak, occurring at moderate temperatures (220–450 °C), are associated with the reduction of CuO, which interacts more strongly with the support, NiO interacting with Cu, or NiO with weak support interactions [46–48]. The fourth peak, seen at high temperatures (> 400 °C), is attributed to NiO particles strongly interacting with the support material [46,49]. The deconvolution can be found in the ESI as Fig. S5 and table S2. The alumina- and Siral-supported catalysts exhibit a more intense high-temperature reduction peak, associated with strongly bound NiO species on the support compared to the SiO2-supported catalysts, indicating a strong metal-support interaction with γ-Al2O3. The relatively low reduction temperatures obtained on the SiO2-supported catalysts indicate that the Ni oxides and Cu oxides are interacting with each other, severely reducing the reduction temperature of Ni oxides [25]. It is less pronounced for the γ-Al2O3/Siral1-supported catalysts due to the stronger interactions of the reducible metals with the support, typically resulting in higher reduction temperatures [50]. The addition of La has an impact on the reduction characteristics as the peak profiles differ from the unpromoted NiCu catalysts. The deconvoluted peaks (Fig. S5 and table S2) indicate a decrease in surface of peak 2 and an increase of peak 3 upon introduction of La, for all supports, but since these are attributed to the same phenomena, no further interpretation is possible. The surface under the first and fourth peak remain very similar upon La introduction. Furthermore, the peaks of both the La-promoted alumina-based and Siral-based catalysts have shifted to slightly lower reduction temperatures, which is attributed to an increase in metal dispersion [51,52]. Based on the TPR analysis, a temperature of 450 °C was chosen for the reduction of the catalysts prior to the reaction. At this temperature, all metal oxides except for finely dispersed NiO, undergo reduction. Notably, the unreducible fraction is about 34% ± 5% (95% confidence interval) of the potentially reducible phases. Higher temperatures were avoided to prevent sintering during the reduction process. 3.1.2 Metal phase properties X-Ray Diffraction (XRD) analysis was conducted to investigate the crystalline phases of the reduced catalysts, and corresponding XRD patterns for the 40°-50° range are shown in Fig. 2 and the full diffractograms in ESI Fig. S6. The XRD pattern of the silica support only displays a broad scattering peak at about 25.00°, indicating its complete amorphous nature. The alumina and Siral supports have an almost identical XRD diffractograms and exhibit semi-crystalline behavior, as confirmed by a scattering peak at 32.70° and diffractions at 46.26° and 67.22°. The SiO2 content in the Siral support amounts only to 1 wt%, which is too small to be detected by XRD analysis. Upon loading with NiCu or La-NiCu, no changes were observed in the support structure based on XRD analysis. At 43.3°, 50.43°, 74.13°, and 89.93° diffractions can be attributed to the formation of a monometallic Cu phase on the surface of the support during reduction. Furthermore, the sharpness of these diffraction peaks suggests that the phase primarily consists of large Cu particles. Prior literature has shown that this diffraction can indeed be related to a bulky Cu phase [25,26,53,54]. Another diffraction peak, between 43.3° and 44.51°, indicates the formation of a NiCu alloy phase. The NiCu alloy its crystalline structure conforms to a face-centered cubic (FCC) lattice, characterized by the fm-3 m space group. This alignment is consistent with the alloy's formation as a solid solution, leveraging the FCC lattice structures inherent in both Ni and Cu. The alloy diffraction appears broader than the pure Cu reflex, suggesting that the alloy particles are smaller than the Cu particles. TEM, shown in ESI Fig. S7, generally verifies the XRD findings, with a mean particle size and standard deviation of 15.9 ± 4.1 nm. Bulky particles were seen in TEM and verified to be Cu with EDX, shown in ESI Fig. S8. Additionally, small alloy particles were found that were clumped together into larger clusters. On the γ-Al2O3 and Siral supports, the alloy diffraction is less pronounced due to the overlap with the γ-Al2O3 diffractions (Fig. 2). Additionally, smaller and well-dispersed alloy particles may have formed on the γ-Al2O3 surface due to stronger metal-support interactions. Finally, a diffraction peak at 43.27° for the γ-Al2O3- and Siral-based materials corresponds to a NiO phase on the γ-Al2O3 support [26,55]. This diffraction is relatively small and broad, which distinguishes it from the Cu reflex, indicating a well-dispersed phase. This observation aligns with the expectation that reducing the materials at 450 °C does not lead to complete reduction of the NiO phase. Both larger Cu particles and smaller sub-10 nm particles are observed in the sample via TEM and via EDX, with a mean particle size and standard deviation of 7.9 ± 3.4 nm and 11.9 ± 3.6 nm for the γ-Al2O3- and Siral-based catalyst, respectively. The crystallite size of the NiCu nanoparticles was not determined via the Scherrer equation due to considerable overlap with adjacent phases, rendering an accurate determination impossible via conventional techniques. However, distinguishing between NiO and NiCu via EDX was not possible due to the small particle sizes. The signal counts from these particles were comparable to the background noise levels, making it difficult to differentiate between NiO and NiCu. Sequentially adding La, prior to NiCu impregnation, resulted in a decrease of the monometallic Cu0 diffraction peak for the γ-Al2O3- and Siral-supported catalysts. It has been shown previously in literature that’ La stabilizes Cu0, which limits its agglomeration into a bulky Cu phase, likely during calcination [26,31,56]. By limiting the agglomeration, a higher degree of contact between Cu and Ni is enabled, thus promoting their alloy formation. Correspondingly, the relative abundance of NiCu alloy phase on the surface of the support increases upon introduction of La. No significant distinction is observed between the unpromoted and promoted у-Al2O3 catalysts in TEM analysis, shown in the ESI Fig. S7. However, in the case of Siral, the catalyst seems to be more uniform in terms of metal particle size after the addition of La, based on TEM. For the SiO2-based catalyst, no clear effect is noticed on the bulk crystalline properties. SiO2 supports are known to exhibit weaker interactions with Ni and Cu compared to the other supports used in this work [57,58]. In this case, the addition of only 0.5 wt% La is unlikely to provide sufficient stabilization to overcome this limitation and achieve effective stabilization. Previous literature suggests that a higher loading of La, specifically 5 wt%, is required to enhance the dispersion of Ni on a SiO2 support in comparable monometallic Ni catalyst systems [59]. Via TEM it is observed that the promoted SiO2 catalyst did not have a clumped dispersion like the unpromoted catalyst, and that the nanoparticles did not have a uniform particle size. However, according to XRD, the bulk crystalline properties do not change after La addition. 3.2 Catalyst screening The specific catalyst activity, described as a reaction rate at 200 °C and 50 bar H2 pressure, is shown in Table 1. The yields towards the various reaction products as a function of the conversion are shown in Fig. 3 (and selectivities in the ESI Fig. S9-10). The initial hydrogenation rate decreases in the following order: NiCu-Al > NiCu-Siral > NiCu-Si, correlating well with the strength of the metal-support interactions [60,61]. These interactions generally lead to smaller and more active alloy particles, in line with the TEM results. Correspondingly, a decrease in mean particle size correlates well with an increase in initial hydrogenation rate. Furthermore, there could also be a difference in electronic effects, due to the presence of NiO and acid sites on the alumina-based supports (Table 1). The presence of these electronic effects can cause a slight shift in the average energy of the d-band center of the alloy, resulting in a distinct activity [62]. The selectivities at lower conversions (< 60%) are similar, i.e. the yields in function of conversion were identical across all catalysts (Fig. 3), and thus follow the reaction paths displayed in Fig. 4. First 4-(2-furanyl)-3-buten-2-one (FAc) is hydrogenated to 4-(2-furanyl)-butan-2-one (HFAc). This hydrogenation occurs at such high rates that almost all of the FAc has been converted into HFAc within just 5 minutes of reaction time. The direct hydrogenation of FAc to HFAc is the predominant pathway, with negligible contribution from parallel reactions involving the hydrogenation of the aliphatic double bond. Therefore, in the remainder of this work, a modified conversion (XFAc-HFAc), in which HFAc is considered as non-converted FAc as elaborated in section 2.3.2, is used. HFAc can further react to either 4-(2-furanyl)-butan-2-ol (HFOH) or 4-(2-tetrahydrofuryl)-butan-2-one (THFAc), depending on whether the ketone group or the furanic ring respectively hydrogenates first. THFAc and HFOH can hereafter both hydrogenate to 4-(2-tetrahydrofuryl)-butan-2-ol (THFOH). It is possible that the ketone group is hydrogenated via a Meerwein-Ponndorf-Verley reduction with isopropyl alcohol as hydrogen donor [23,63]. As a side reaction, HFOH can also form 2-methyl-1,6-dioxaspiro[4,4]nonane (Diox) through an intramolecular addition of the hydroxyl group. At higher conversions (> 60%), a difference between the non-acidic support and the acidic support is observed. The reaction on the non-acidic SiO2-supported does not proceed beyond THFOH, while acidic γ-Al2O3-supported catalysts are able to form 2-butyltetrahydrofuran (BTHF) from THFOH. Acid sites are, hence, required to form BTHF via dehydration and subsequent rapid hydrogenation of THFOH. Alternatively, it has been reasoned in literature that ring-opened products are formed out of non-saturated rings, such as HFOH [23,64,65]. DFT calculations have shown that 2,3-dihydrofuran is a reactive intermediate for both hydrogenation and ring opening, while subsequent hydrogenation products of the furanic ring did not favor ring opening due to high energy barriers [65]. Diox can also further convert into octane via several reaction steps, as proposed by Ramos et al [18], involving ring-opening and dehydration reactions. Similar selectivities for both alumina and Siral-based catalysts were observed due to similar acidity between γ-Al2O3 and Siral, as observed in NH3-TPD (Table 1 and Fig. S2). Further conversion of BTHF (or Diox, HFOH as mentioned above) results in the formation of octane, up to 2.5% yield after 240 min of reaction, see Fig. S6. Similar reaction pathways have been proposed in literature before for Pt-based catalysts [18,23]. Both 2-butyltetrahydrofuran and octane are of interest within the context of biofuels [66]. The specific activity always increases upon sequential addition of La, see Table 1. The yield profile however remains similar, see Fig. 3 (and the selectivities in the ESI Fig. S9-10), indicating that the nature of the active sites does not change upon La addition. Generally, the addition of La to a NiCu alloy will shift the average energy of the d-band center closer to the Fermi level due to La's nearly empty d-shell, resulting in increased adsorption strength of the reactants and intermediates, as confirmed by Density of States calculations, see ESI [67]. This ultimately can lead to an increased activity. The SiO2 catalysts did not differ in bulk structure according to XRD after La addition. The only observed difference is in a decrease of the uniformity of the catalyst after La addition, observed in TEM (ESI Fig. S7). This lack in uniformity results in more sub-10-nm alloy particles that are present on the surface of the La-promoted SiO2 support compared to the unpromoted catalyst. These small alloy particles may be responsible for the majority of the observed activity. The alumina- and Siral-based catalysts both have less agglomerated Cu0 and more NiCu alloy after sequential La impregnation, as confirmed by XRD. An increase in alloy nanoparticle surface, which provides active sites for hydrogenation, thus translates into a higher initial specific hydrogenation rate (Table 1). Moreover, the dispersion and uniformity of the Siral-supported catalyst improved, from a mean particle size of 11.9 ± 3.6 nm to 7.4 ± 3.5 nm after addition of La, which also gives rise to an activity increase. Finally, a continuous flow experiment was performed to assess the stability of the La-promoted catalysts. The unpromoted catalysts were not subjected to the assessment, as their La impregnated counterparts exhibit overall better performances. The conversion and selectivities were plotted versus the Time-On-Stream (TOS) in Fig. 5. Notably, the SiO2-based catalyst deactivates fast, dropping about 20% in conversion after a mere 5 h of TOS. In contrast, the Al2O3- and Siral-based catalysts appear to be substantially more stable, with only a 3% decrease in conversion. Considering that the starting point, at 99% conversion, for the latter catalysts is, in fact, too high for a pure stability assessment, another observation that confirms the stability of these materials is that the selectivity remains unchanged as a function of TOS. The obtained selectivities are moreover similar to the ones obtained in the batch experiment. According to literature, at conditions similar to the ones applied here, sintering is typically not the cause of deactivation, instead a change in catalyst morphology and coke deposition are cited as the predominant cause [19]. The TGA-MS results, shown in the ESI Fig. S11-13, confirm the presence of carbonaceous deposits on all spent catalysts, regardless from the support used. The SiO2-based catalyst displays the most pronounced difference in relative mass loss between its fresh and spent states, approximately 7.5%, while the Al2O3 and Siral-based catalysts show only a 1.5 wt% difference. This indicates that La-NiCu-Si manifests the most pronounced coking behavior among the 3 evaluated materials. Furthermore, there is a noticeable disparity in the temperature at which these cokes are burned off, around ± 400 °C for La-NiCu-Si, compared to ± 290 °C for La-NiCu-Al and La-NiCu-Siral, indicating variations in the type of cokes being removed. Soft coke, related to more mobile carbonaceous residues or physisorbed products or side-products, is thus found on the catalysts using an acidic support [68]. Bulkier carbonaceous compounds such as polynuclear aromatic compounds, i.e. hard coke, are found on the non-acidic supported catalyst [68,69]. It appears that the acid sites of у-Al2O3 protect the catalyst from forming hard coke, possibly because the coke precursors preferentially adsorb on the acid sites, leading to the formation of soft coke. The La-promoted NiCu on γ-Al2O3 or Siral catalysts are superior compared to the other catalysts, due to their high activity, selectivity towards deoxygenated products and stability. La-NiCu-Al was selected to study the impact of H2 total pressure and reaction temperature, although it is expected that the obtained results will be representative for the La-NiCu-Siral catalyst as well. 3.3 Impact of H2 pressure and reaction temperature The H2 total pressure was varied between 40 bar and 70 bar in batch at 200 °C to assess its impact, using the La-NiCu-Al catalyst, shown in Fig. 6 (A-D) (and the selectivities in the ESI Fig. S14). No clear effect is observed on the reaction rate as it remained at 76.1 ± 1.3 mol kgcat −1 h−1 when the H2 pressure is varied. The selectivity profile as a function of reaction time also remained similar, indicating that hydrogen availability is not limiting. It has been shown previously in literature that using isopropyl alcohol resulted in an improved hydrogenation activity compared to other protic solvents, due to hydrogen transfer from the protic solvent on the metal surface or due to inter-hydride transfers over Lewis acidic sites [20]. This hydrogenation activity ensures that the availability of hydrogen is not a concern over the measured range. In contrast, systems with aprotic solvents, such as cyclohexane, have seen an impact on the catalyst performance with varying H2 pressure in a similar range [22]. To gain more insight into the role of externally applied H2, a H2-free atmosphere was applied by pressuring the batch reactor with N2 instead. At 40 and 70 bar N2 total pressure, the activity of the catalyst remains high at 64.0 ± 4.4 mol kgcat −1 h−1, with a decrease compared to the system with externally applied H2. Isopropyl alcohol can thus serve as an excellent hydrogen donor via its hydrogen transfer, inter-hydride transfers or dehydrogenation reaction. The dehydrogenation of an alcohol can occur over Cu and NiCu active sites at the employed operating conditions [32,70]. The reduced initial activity is most likely the result of a lack of hydrogen at the start which results in a reduced initial hydrogenation rate. Once sufficient hydrogen is generated the reduced hydrogenation rate is largely mitigated, yielding similar yield profiles as the catalysts in a H2 atmosphere, presented in Fig. 6 (E-F). The yield profile does not seem to be affected remarkably by using a N2 atmosphere in a batch reactor, indicating again that hydrogen generation is not affected notably in the measured pressure range. The temperature is increased from 200 °C to 220 °C to evaluate its effect on the activity and selectivity, see Fig. 7 (and the selectivities in the ESI Fig. S15-16). A temperature increase lead to an activity increase from 76.1 ± 1.3–77.8 mol kgcat −1 h−1 and from 64.0 ± 4.4–80.1 mol kgcat −1 h−1, in both a H2 and N2 atmosphere respectively. The selectivity to BTHF and octane increases while the selectivity towards HFOH decreases. Ring opening is thus promoted at elevated temperatures, which has been observed in literature as well for Pt-based catalysts [18]. A further increase in temperature should increase the octane selectivity even more, but could also negatively impact the stability of the materials. Finally, a continuous flow experiment was conducted to investigate the impact of using a H2-free atmosphere on the stability of the La-NiCu-Al catalyst, shown in Fig. 8. The catalyst exhibits faster deactivation in a N2 atmosphere than in a H2 atmosphere. This observation is evident in both the conversion profiles and the selectivity profiles as a function of TOS. In the absence of external H2, the dehydrogenation of isopropyl alcohol results in the production of acetone. Under these conditions, aldol condensation reactions could potentially occur between the reactants, products, and acetone itself over the acidic sites of γ-Al2O3, ultimately leading to condensation under the form of cokes [71,72]. Uncontrolled aldol condensation would not necessarily occur in the batch reactor, as in that reactor configuration all the reactant gets converted at once over a certain time period, while in continuous flow there will always be a portion of the bed that converts fresh, newly fed, reactant, i.e. ketones required for aldol condensation. The catalyst thus experiences a deactivation profile in continuous flow, where the beginning of the catalyst bed deactivates while the end remains active. Consequently, as the space time in a continuous flow decreases due to deactivation, the selectivity changes due to a difference in conversion. Furthermore, the dehydrogenation of isopropyl alcohol alone may contribute to the formation of coke deposits, as has been seen in literature for similar catalysts [32]. It is clear that external H2 is thus not required for the activity of the catalyst since both in the batch and the continuous experiment the reaction proceeds without it, but it has a positive impact on the catalyst stability. The TGA-MS results, presented in the ESI Fig. S12, indicate that a higher amount of cokes has been formed on the catalyst used in the N2 atmosphere, showing a difference of 1.5% in relative mass lost compared to the one employed in the H2 atmosphere. Additionally, a new peak at approximately 400 °C is observed, which was associated with the formation of hard coke and stronger deactivation in Section 3.2, likely linked to the dehydrogenation reaction [68]. Not only the deactivation behavior, but also the selectivities seem to differ depending on the gas used, which was not observed in batch systems. It is observed that the dehydration reaction proceeds more effectively in a N2 environment, which cannot be rationalized at this point: the absence of hydrogen can not only change surface coverages and reaction pathways, but it can as well cause a more oxidized state of the catalyst, which likely enhances dehydration reactions [73]. Further comprehensive post-reaction characterization, including investigations into metal leaching and the utilization of synchrotron-based methods to determine the oxidation state of the catalyst, is deemed necessary for a deeper understanding. However, these are considered out of scope for this screening study. In conclusion, the use of a reductive H2 atmosphere is crucial to ensure long term catalyst stability. 4 Conclusions This work has evaluated the potential of (La-)NiCu catalysts for the hydrodeoxygenation of 4-(2-furanyl)-3-buten-2-one. Various catalyst supports differing in acidity have been explored, along with the sequential addition of a promotor element, La, to the catalyst. It is clear from the results that the acidity of the support has a determining role in the reaction selectivity. Catalysts with non-acidic supports only exhibit hydrogenation behavior, while the ones with acidic supports are able to open the furanic ring. Acid sites are thus required for a full HDO. The metal-support interactions proved to be an important factor. Stronger interactions lead to smaller NiCu alloy particles and correspondingly a higher activity. Among the investigated supports, γ-Al2O3 exhibits the strongest metal-support interactions, followed by Siral and SiO2, in decreasing order. Furthermore, the incorporation of La further enhances the activity by reducing the particle size and, in the case of γ-Al2O3 and Siral, increasing the amount of NiCu alloy. The catalyst stability is also impacted by metal-support interactions, with the SiO2-based catalyst showing significant, while Al2O3 and Siral-based catalysts proves to be much more stable, in the investigated timeframe. The presence of isopropyl alcohol as a solvent ensures sufficient hydrogen availability, as it proves to be an effective hydrogen donor for the hydrodeoxygenation process. At the investigated conditions, isopropyl alcohol in an inert atmosphere allows a for similar activity and selectivity without requiring a reductive H2 atmosphere. However, a H2 atmosphere is still needed to maintain the stability of the catalyst materials, confirmed via continuous flow experiments. In short, this work demonstrates the potential of NiCu catalysts using acidic supports for the hydrodeoxygenation of aldol condensation products of furfural and acetone. Although complete ring opening is not obtained due to the challenges associated with opening a fully hydrogenated furan ring, further investigations could explore more severe conditions, solvents with reduced hydrogenation promotion or modifications of the support to further enhance the strength of acid sites. The stability of the catalysts in other solvents warrants exploration. Furthermore, studying the contribution of external H2 and H2 provided by a protic solvent, and how a different catalyst can impact the dehydrogenation rate of the solvent, could provide valuable insights for future research endeavors. In addition, varying the amount of La loaded could offer a deeper understanding of its effects in subsequent studies. In addition, the amount of La loaded could be varied to more fundamentally study its effects in future work. coredata.dc:description: Aiming at the valorization of furfural-derived compounds, the potential of (La-)NiCu catalysts for the hydrodeoxygenation of 4-(2-furanyl)-3-buten-2-one has been assessed. The impact of support acidity and the effects of modifying the support with La have been explored. While catalysts with non-acidic supports solely lead to hydrogenation, the acid sites enable furanic ring opening. Additionally, changing the support alters the metal-support interaction strength, with stronger interactions reducing the NiCu alloy particle size and increasing activity. Furthermore, according to Density of States calculations, La further enhances the hydrodeoxygenation activity by increasing the adsorption strength. Also, for the acidic supports, it increases the relative abundance of NiCu alloy on the support surface, further increasing the specific activity. The La-NiCu-Al catalyst demonstrated was the best performing catalyst at 200 °C and 40 bar H2, achieving a high conversion rate of 77 mol kgcat −1 h−1 with a combined selectivity of 29 % towards octane and BTHF at 99 % conversion, and stability over 5 hours Time-On-Stream. Additionally, isopropyl alcohol proved to be an excellent hydrogen donor, as the external H2 pressure does not substantially impact the catalyst activity and selectivity, but H2 itself proved to be important for the catalyst stability.
coredata.dc:title: Potential of (La-)NiCu catalysts for the hydrodeoxygenation of 4-(2-furanyl)-3-buten-2-one into fuels: Investigation of support and La addition
